data.title: Peers may throw out David Cameron's plans to allow gay marriages in church
data.meta_description: DAVID Cameron’s pledge to allow gay marriages in churches could be thrown out by angry Tory peers.
data.text:
DAVID Cameron’s pledge to allow gay marriages in churches could be thrown out by angry Tory peers.

A motion put forward by Conservative peer Baroness O’Cathain could kill the proposal, effectively kicking it into the long grass, Government sources have revealed.

Senior Lib Dems were furious with the Tories for stealing their party’s policy and announcing it as their own at their annual conference.

Lib Dem and Labour critics argued that Mr Cameron’s announcement – that the Tories under his leadership backed gay marriage – was a cynical political ploy to “detoxify” his party in the eyes of voters.

Baroness O’Cathain’s amendment to the Bill covering civil partnerships now threatens to wreck the Prime Minister’s bid to show the Tories as a modern, liberal party.

The policy has been championed by Lib Dem Equalities Minister Lynne Featherstone and she is said to be “dismayed” it could be scuppered.

But Baroness O’Cathain claims the proposal does “not fulfil the Government’s pledge to protect properly faith groups from being compelled to register civil partnerships where it is against their beliefs”.
